summary: "Fargo" is a reality-based crime drama set in Minnesota in 1987. Jerry Lundegaard (William H. Macy) is a car salesman in Minneapolis who has gotten himself into debt and is so desperate for money that he hires two thugs (Steve Buscemi), (Peter Stormare) to kidnap his own wife. Jerry will collect the ransom from her wealthy father (Harve Presnell), paying the thugs a small portion and keeping the rest to satisfy his debts. The scheme collapses when the thugs shoot a state trooper.

reviews.content:
Fargo is a masterpiece of modern cinema that captivates audiences with its unique blend of dark humor, suspenseful storytelling, and memorable characters. Directed by Joel and Ethan Coen, this 1996 film is widely regarded as one of the best crime-comedy films of all time, and for good reason.

One of the standout elements that makes Fargo so good is its exceptional screenplay. The Coen brothers' writing is a masterclass in storytelling, filled with sharp dialogue, unexpected twists, and a darkly comedic tone. The film's plot follows a seemingly simple plan gone wrong, as a bungled kidnapping scheme in a small town in Minnesota sets off a chain of events that spiral out of control. The Coen brothers' ability to balance tension and humor is remarkable, creating a unique tone that keeps audiences on the edge of their seats while also making them burst into laughter.

The characters in Fargo are another major highlight of the film. From the quirky and bumbling Jerry Lundegaard, played by William H. Macy, to the persistent and unflappable Marge Gunderson, portrayed by Frances McDormand in an Oscar-winning performance, the cast is filled with memorable personalities. The Coen brothers excel at creating complex and multi-dimensional characters that feel both real and absurd at the same time, adding depth and richness to the story.

The film's setting and atmosphere also play a crucial role in its success. The frigid and desolate landscapes of Minnesota, captured beautifully by the Coen brothers' longtime collaborator, cinematographer Roger Deakins, provide a stark contrast to the dark and violent events that unfold on screen. The juxtaposition of the serene snowy landscapes with the chaos and brutality of the crime story creates a unique and unforgettable visual experience.

Furthermore, the film's use of dark humor is a masterstroke. The Coen brothers have a knack for finding humor in the most unexpected and absurd situations, and Fargo is no exception. The film's dry and deadpan humor provides a stark contrast to the violent and chaotic events that occur, adding an element of levity to the dark and gruesome story.

It's meticulous attention to detail is another reason why it stands out as a masterpiece. From the meticulously crafted accents and dialects of the characters, which add to the film's authenticity, to the carefully chosen props and costumes that enhance the story's quirks and idiosyncrasies, every aspect of the film is thoughtfully designed to create a cohesive and immersive experience for the viewers.

Fargo is a brilliantly crafted film that excels in every aspect of filmmaking. Its exceptional screenplay, memorable characters, unique setting and atmosphere, skillful use of dark humor, and meticulous attention to detail all contribute to its status as a true classic. If you haven't seen Fargo yet, it's a must-watch for any film lover, and for those who have, it's worth revisiting to appreciate its brilliance once again.

Fargo is a mix of drama/comedy with a plot about kidnapping involving small town folks and some criminals.  The movie was done by the Coen Brothers and the end result is a movie that manages to be simultaneously hilarious, dramatic and sometimes sad.

William H Macy is perfectly cast as Jerry Lundegard, a car salesman at a dealership owned by his father in law who by all indications, dislikes Jerry immensely. Jerry doesn't seem cut out for the job as he cons an angry customer into adding an additional few hundred dollars of sealant to the car. Jerry is also evidently in some big financial trouble.

The plot the whole movie is centered around is Jerry hiring two sleazy criminals, Carl Showalter (Steve Buscemi) and Gaear Grimsrud (Peter Stormare)  to kidnap his wife Jean, played well by Kristin Rudrud. The whole plan goes off the rails  and chaos ensues. The heart of the movie is a kind police officer named Marge Gunderson (played fantastically by Frances McDormand). The movie has trademark brilliant dialogue and characters as is usual of Coen Brother movies. I highly recommend this flick, extremely entertaining.

Such a simple black comedy with a simple plot is pure entertainment from the very first scene.  William H. Macy is Jerry, a sales manager at a car dealership owned by his very wealthy father in law and owing a debt of money, meets two shady characters at a seedy bar in Fargo, North Dakota to set up to have his wife kidnapped by Carl (Steve Buschemi) and his silent accomplice Gaear (Peter Stormare).  His plan to have his wealthy father in law pay the ransom to Carl and Gaear and give Jerry half to pay off his debt in exchange for a brand new car.  In Minneapolis, Minnesota, the kidnapping goes off successfully but things soon go wrong when they're pulled over by a state trooper in Brainerd Minnesota for failing to display the proper tags on the new car.  This leads to a triple homicide and the kidnappers now demanding the full ransom from Jerry for their now severe crimes.  Even worse, Jerry's father in law insists on getting involved with the money exchange making matters worse for Jerry.
Enter Marge (Frances McDormamd), a very pregnant chief of police who's as smart as she is sweet investigating the crimes in Brainerd and Minneapolis.  Now with Marge on his tail, things become even worse for Jerry.  His father in law is murdered during the botched money exchange and he's left with no money and his wife is eventually killed by her kidnappers.  In a stroke of luck, Marge finds the car in question along with Gaear who is brutally offing his partner Carl after a brief alteration.  With Gaear in custody and Jerry now arrested, Marge simply returns to bed with his husband satisfied with another case closed.
Directed by the Cohen brothers, they spent so much time on little details from the characters speaking in Minnesota dialect to their mannerisms and no details in explaining any character's motives for their crimes.  Who was Jerry in debt with?  Why did they kill his wife anyway?  Did Marge have a boy or a girl?  Thing is, there was so need to get into that sort of detail to make this film so entertaining and endearing in spite of some brutal violence.  The Cohen's kept it simple and fast paced as to not weigh the story down with plot details that could've spoiled the story.  It's wonderfully performed by the entire cast and absurdly funny.  Is this a remarkable film?  As the characters would say, You darn tootin', ja!

This is a somewhat quirky, small town type drama watch. The plot is a little slow paced perhaps and its not constantly action packed but its intriguing enough to keep you watching regardless. There are good performances from Buscemi and McDormand (perhaps slightly less so from William H Macy) and some fairly amusing aspects of the very much dark comedy plot. I have to say I didn't find it overall an especially funny watch, in the way I maybe expected, given its quite a cult classic but its certainly not bad. I felt particularly sorry for Buscemi's character, Carl Showalter. I note that the characters names are a bit quirky, much like the people themselves - somewhat animated at times, while also appearing physically fairly average. For a Coen brothers film, its not bad but not my favourite. It seemed to me to be a tale of botched criminality, with the most memorable aspect being that its set in a very snowy and dreary semi-rural area of the US, which makes the red blood of the violence stand out. It may make you cringe but yeah, I suppose I would recommend it overall.

I can't quite say that this is a masterpiece, but it has a certain special something.  I appreciate the classic "film" look. It predates digital movies and so it has a certain nostalgic vibe which is very worth appreciating.  The story kept me engaged, but not without moments where I derided it for demonstrating very unrealistic behavior, notwithstanding the fact that this is supposedly based upon a true story.  What bugs me is not so much a criticism of the movie, but rather the lack of appreciation for human life a couple of the criminals in the story have.  In any case, I barely remembered anything from seeing this over 20 years ago, so I decided to give it a whirl.  My time was well spent.  I liked the performances and it kept my attention rather nicely.  I don't imagine watching it again, but I'm glad that I resisted it.

In a career that is never slowing down and constantly evolving, Fargo is often considered the Coen brothers best work and while arguable, it's easy to see why.

One of the Coen Brothers' best films. It has an amazing sense of place (wonderfully captured by Roger Deakins' cinematography) and is almost downright poetic in its local dialect. Frances McDormand is an enchanting presence at the center of this, bringing warmth and cheerfulness to her police chief role. A terrific crime reconstruction scene tips us that her character is smarter than her Minnesota accent lets on, and McDormand play it with splendid subtlety. Just as good is John Carroll Lynch as her adoring husband. William H. Macy gives one of those memorable "average joe in over his head" performances. Steve Buscemi is perfectly cast as a "funny lookin'" twitchy con man. Peter Stomare is scary as ruthless killer who doesn't hardly speak. The Coens deftly weave human comedy and wry observations with graphic, sometimes cruel violence. This is a dark comedy, but an optimistic one. It pulls you in and doesn't let go until the very end. It may not be "important," but this is just great storytelling at its finest

What a great movie - especially being from the Midwest, a lot of topics and mannerisms really hit home. A well-written 90's crime thriller with greatly paced storyline that keeps you watching until the end.

"Fargo" is one of those rare films that feels like a true cultural phenomenon; a work that ingeniously navigates the boundaries between eccentricity and relatability while synthesizing a resonant portrait of life playfully revealing the lurid darkness quietly lurking beneath the disarming veneer of Midwestern pleasantry. It is both comic and tragic, ambitious and down to earth, quirky and yet seemingly homespun. It creates a sense of transcending all orthodox genre boundaries, enveloping us in an innovative style that is always tickling the senses and leaving us guessing. It feels like a celebration of the ordinary which is itself wholly extraordinary; a mischievous invitation to the viewer to dwell among the characters as they mingle and jostle in ever-so-polite ways. "Fargo" will surely be remembered as a true landmark of cinema for generations to come and deserves to be treasured as an American masterpiece like none other.

It's an entertaining story, that's for certain! Around 98 minutes was a wise run time call, also. I didn't get that extra little something from it, yet it's a film that I'd more than happily rewatch - largely thanks to McDormand, and Buscemi.

Macy and Frances McDormand also both give wonderful performances with especially convincing Minnesotan accents and mannerisms (ah, jeez...). The story is somehow ridiculous enough to be believable (which is good, because it's a true story). 

The atmosphere throughout beautifully captures the cold isolation of Midwestern rural winters, helped by the fact that it was actually filmed in snow-covered Minnesota and North Dakota, and also by the looming Paul Bunyan statue (one of my favorite shots). The film does a great job of building tension at making you root for the morally corrupt main character, but taking a step back and looking at the bigger picture makes the ending satisfying while still absolutely hilarious.

Leave it to the Coen Brothers to take a seemingly standard crime caper and elevate it to a level rarely seen within the genre.  Such is the case with Fargo, the story of a financially desperate man (William H Macy) who conspires with a pair of petty criminals (Steve Buscemi, Peter Stormare) to kidnap his wife and collect the ransom money from his father-in-law.  When murder and mayhem ensue, it is left to pregnant police office Marge Gunderson (Frances McDormand) to clean things up.  As in most movies by the Coens, the dialogue is brilliant and the characters are carefully etched.  Add to this the beautifully captured landscape of barren fields covered in snow and an ingenious plot and you are left with what may be the Coens finest film.  The relevance of the Mike Yanagita scene will always be open for debate, but that's a minor quibble in what is otherwise a masterpiece.

Jerry Lundegard runs his father-in-law's car dealership in Minnesota who always seems to be in massive financial trouble for one reason or another. Even after possible embezzlement at Jerry's place of work he still must go to absolute drastic measures. Thats when Jerry puts a scheme in motion to hire two out of area criminals to kidnap his wife in order to push his father-in-law to pay a million dollar ransom without his direct involvement. The hired men, Wade & Gaear, are successful in kidnapping Jerry's wife Jean but on the way to the safe house an unfortunate event leaves three people left in bloodshed. As Jerry attempts to mend the situation to keep the gears in motion and Wade & Gaear seemingly unravel a pesky, persistent, and very pregnant Sheriff Marge Gunderson is tenaciously motivated to unearth the truth of the murders so justice can be served.   

This film manages to be quite a poignant piece of filmmaking but in all regards deep within has beauty in it. Joel and Ethan Coen have always been fantastic storytellers but Fargo takes the cake with its twists, turns, and many layers leaves the viewer guessing until the very end. This is a very dark true story the pulls no punches in its brutality. The acting was phenomenal, the cinematography beautiful, and the musical score was on point. Might I add this cast is absolutely stacked even by todays standards. This is a 90's classic you need to add to your watchlist.

The first big hit by the directing duo Joel and Ethan Coen really heralded the somewhat different kind of filmmaking. Further films like No Country For Old Men, A Serious Man or True Grit followed and finally established the Coen Brothers as masters of their craft. Fargo contains all the elements that their style stands for: unorthodox violence, the discreet incorporation of comedic aspects and a plot that seems very simple at first glance, but which brings much more meaning and hidden social criticism after watching the film several times.

Besides the Coen Brothers, the film was also the big breakthrough of acting icon Frances McDormand. Her character Marge Gunderson does not appear as often as one would expect from the "main character". When she is seen, she delights with her amiable nature, which is topped off by her stubborn naivety and belief in the good. McDormand also masters the Minnesota accent perfectly, which only makes her character more likeable and refreshing. She is never really aware of the gravity of the situation at any point and is constantly miles off the mark as the police officer in charge of the occurring crime. William H. Macy's slightly crazy character Jerry Lundegaard is the centre of the film at the beginning. The main action starts from him and he is pretty much the opposite of Marge: he always knows what is going on and is shady without end. Although he has no real evil intentions, pretty much all of his plans go awry, leaving him constantly on the run and always quick to lose his cool. Macy plays big and makes this shambles of a man weirdly likeable. Steve Buscemi and Peter Stormare are responsible for the more brutal moments as the crooks and are hilarious in their scenes together because of the difference of their characters.

It is not for nothing that a television series of the same name was developed based on Fargo. The peculiarity of this film still has a cult following for many. Also beautiful to look at is the completely snowed-in Minnesota and the cast covered in fur coats. The performances by McDormand, Macy and Buscemi of course help the plot, which is a little dull towards the middle, enormously. It picks up towards the end without offering a big showdown or explosive finale. Fargo is generally a rather quietly constructed film that uses its violent scenes very selectively. What is so impressive is the socio-critical factor behind it. There is a clear demarcation between good and bad people. The Coen Brothers are not above depicting this in sometimes very subtle but also extreme ways. Fargo is rightly an important part of film history that should be watched alone for the fact that the Coen Brothers really took off with it.
The darkest funniest classic of all time.

I genuinely loved Fargo. I think that it's a must-see crime drama. It is a film that manages to achieve a balance... it is dark, but it's also funny. The kind of comedy portrayed in Fargo is dark humor, obviously, but that just adds more grace to it. Mix violence with a good black comedy can mean two things: massive disaster or an incredibly smart movie, and Fargo achieved the second option. It is a very interesting story, with good acting and memorable scenes. It is violent, dark, a very well-constructed crime story, yet funny, interesting and absolutely fresh.

Fargo is actually a brilliant movie and it's honestly a masterpiece and a half. The movie's got such a brilliant story with such a strong script, which has been well written.

The movie's got some brilliant performances from each character throughout this movie, especially from Carl (Steve Buscemi) he's honestly amazing throughout this movie.

The dialogue which is given from each character throughout this movie is honestly very strong dialogue, each piece of dialogue is received so beautifully and it's so well done.

Also, the movie's got some great humour from each character throughout this movie. All of the humour throughout this movie works really well in making me laugh in some sort of way.

The movie's pacing is honestly great, each main moment is built up so well and non of the moments start to feel like they drag, which is quite good.

The movie's cinematographer Roger Deakins does such a beautiful job on capturing each moment so beautifully. He's honestly one of the best cinematographers to this day, he always does such a beautiful job on capturing these moments so beautifully.

Finally, the movie's got some very gory moments scattered throughout, they're all very well made. Also, the gory moments are all well built up with the great pacing throughout this movie and they all work so perfectly well.

The makeup artist who's called John Blake does such a brilliant job on making the gory look to the characters come to life.

Overall, Fargo is honestly a brilliant movie and it's even a masterpiece and a half. The movie's got a brilliant story, brilliant performances, strong dialogue, great humour, great pacing, beautiful cinematography, lots of gory moments and a brilliant makeup artist.

Fargo is a crime thriller based around a botched kidnapping plot. The Coen brothers deserve praise for their storytelling in this film as well as bringing each character down to earth for the audience. One thing that makes this film so powerful is how it brought down everyone to levels we can understand. These can be our family members, neighbors, even used-car dealers.  Nearly every character and setting is memorable in this film. Who doesn't wish they had a Marge Gunderson (Frances McDormand) on their team??

Another aspect I enjoyed about this film is the unpredictability of the plot. The events in the film feel believable and are not absurd. Everyone's motive is clear and upfront and there's no nerfing of the plot.

Not to mention the goriness and grotesque murders contrasted with the cheeriness of peak Midwestern quirkiness.  The film combines both nihilism and comedy in an entrancing package.

Also, shoutout to Roger Deakins for that AMAZING cinematography in the film!

Part tense crime drama, part hilarious dark comedy, Fargo excels as another entry into the Cohen's nihilistic filmography. It features great performances from Steve Buscemi, and in particular Frances McDormand, who definitely deserved her best actress award. Her subtle performance contrasts the usual hard-boiled police detective with a kind almost motherly character, who is just trying to get her job done. In particular, her monologue in the police car towards the end and her conversation with her husband, really tie the film together, as she appreciates the smaller things in life, despite the cold, absurd and uncaring reality surrounding her, This makes it a more optimistic entry from the Cohen brothers. The dialogue is hilarious, in particular the exchanges with Steve Buscemi's character, and the old high school friend with mental problems. This film is also yet again beautifully shot by Roger Deakins,  Overall, this film is definitely worth the watch and a good way to pass 1 hour and 40 minutes.

Fargo is as morbid as it is charming, and the two go hand in hand. The film's northern midwest setting adds to its comedy, showing the sickeningly polite lives of the various police officers, witnesses, and civilians. This is in stark contrast to what is undoubtedly the film's best quality- the performance of Steve Buscemi. This might be my favorite role of his, and I just adored seeing his smarmy character onscreen and thee mishaps surrounding his cocky decisions. This is one of those films where pretty much everyone other than the protagonist is an idiot, but it feels realistic rather than frustrating, so I'm laughing at their under-reactions instead of yelling at them through my television. Speaking of the protagonist, I love her. She's a strong and charming female lead who played a great straight man in this plot of blissfully unaware Minnesotans.
My only real critique of this film is that there are several parts of its plot that seem to serve no importance. Protagonist Marge Gunderson (Frances McDormand) has a baby due that is never really brought up except in passing, and yet is addressed right in the last few lines of the film as if it were an important element all along. She also has a friend named Steve (Mike Yanagita) who has a small B-plot that never seems to tie to anything else. But overall, I can put most of that aside as I watch Steve Buscemi yell at everything that mildly perturbs him.

I was very underwhelmed by this film as I had expected to see a classic that made me laugh and feel slightly disturbed at once but instead what I got was a mildly amusing film that was too slight to have real impact. The ‚Äòdark humor' of the film was either so subtle that it was lost on me when it wasn't hitting me over the head or it just made occasional appearances that didn't leave me giggling but occasionally elicited a half smile from me. Part of the problem might be that I have never really connected with the work of the Coen brothers as I don't think that A Serious Man (2009) or No Country for Old Men (2007) are masterpieces and their humor often irritates more than amuses me. Considering the fact that this is seen as one of their best films I did have higher expectations however and even my parents, tough critics, liked this film so I assumed it would be brilliant, it really was not.

Jerry Lundegaard, William H. Macy, decides to organize the kidnapping of his wife in order to extort his wealthy father in law and solve his financial problems. His plan quickly spirals out of control as the kidnappers he hires, Carl, Steve Buscemi, and Gaear, Peter Stormare, accidentally shoot a police officer and his father in law complicates the exchange of the money. Investigating the case is well-meaning police officer Marge Gunderson, Frances McDormand, who uses her sensible nature to solve a difficult case and in the end even Lundegaard receives his comeuppance.

The plot was vaguely entertaining as a farcical series of events in which people's lives became more and more complicated as the stress piled on. The plot wasn't enough to keep me engaged though as I suffered through long scenes of Gunderson going on what was meant to be a funny awkward date with an ex-classmate who lies to her face. The humor sometimes felt like it was getting in the way of what could have been an interesting plot as we cut from interesting scenes of the kidnappers shooting a police officer to Marge and her husband having lunch and speaking in the annoying over the top dialect that the Coens fetishize. I wish that they had settled on a tone or chosen to fully go one way or another because as the film is it's an unsatisfying experience.

The screenplay frustrated me because it's laugh lines felt so self congratulatory and the moments at which we get darker elements felt so contrived. I don't like how they write because so often you end up spending time with characters who have one joke to them that Coens play out over and over again until you just want the film to end. For example, in this film every character says "You, betcha!" at one point and although it was initially a fun little quirk I quickly became tired of hearing it and wanted to see something new on screen despite the film's short length. A movie like this should not feel tiring but the Coens as both writers and directors do not have a handle what film they are really trying to make. There may be a great film buried in here but the Coens don't have the ability to draw it out and at this point I doubt they ever will.

As for McDormand's performance I dispute the idea that she is a leading actress because I felt that she was a supporting character when compared to Lundegaard. I don't think she earned her Academy Award, especially when considering the fact that Emily Watson and Brenda Blethyn were nominated in the same year. She is funny enough and brings a certain warmth and strength to the part but she is not enough to save the film from itself and is clearly being pushed to give a broader performance than is necessary.

For a film that was called one of the greatest of all time I found very little to appreciate and I don't think that modern viewers will either. This is one of those where I truly cannot understand where all the hype comes from and I don't think I will ever watch this film again.

√¢Fargo√¢?, released in in 1996 follows a man who sets up a hostage situation with his wife in order to get a pay-out from her rich father. While watching the film, I thought a lot about how much more complicated the story became when more people got involved. It made me feel anxious when watching it as a result. √¢Fargo√¢? fits into the crime drama by not being a drama and rather a dramedy. Personally, I would have liked if the comedic moments were played up a little more. The comic relief was always Frances McDormand, who I loved. My favorite part of the writing in the film is how complicated and mucky things get as time goes on. An example of this is when Jerry√¢(TM)s father-in-law wants to get involved in dropping off the money and ends up getting shot and killed. In terms of directing, I thought that it was an interesting choice to have Jerry still be carrying the groceries when he√¢(TM)s walking upstairs to see where his wife is. It added to the character√¢(TM)s eagerness to see if his plan worked. My favorite scene in regard to editing is when the robbers are breaking into the house. The shots bounce between the wife√¢(TM)s reaction and the crowbar knocking more and more into the door to the bathroom that she√¢(TM)s hiding in. The editor really took their time with each shot and it really amps up the tension. Frances McDormand as Marge Gunderson is tremendous. I love her √¢can do attitude√¢? and positive spin on everything. When she is first investigating the triple homicide, she views everything matter-of-factly as if she were discussing the weather with someone. Though the cinematography wasn√¢(TM)t my favorite overall, I enjoyed when the robbers are chasing after the guys who spotted them killing the cop. The shot of the road ahead of them is really interesting because half of the shot is the road and half of it is the dark night and you can faintly see the red taillights before them disappear. Strengths: They're held in high regard, but the Coen Brothers have always been kind of hit or miss for me. This one was a hit, as their brand of humor worked wonderfully with the wild situations these characters got put through. William H. Macy (Jerry Lundegaard) and Steve Buscemi (Carl Showalter) were both hilarious in their roles. It's some of the funniest work I've seen from either of them. Frances McDormand (Marge Gunderson) was her usual fantastic self. The script is witty and filled with sharp dialogue, while there are plenty of moments that manage to surprise you. There are several violent scenes that are done with the right cadence, making sure they fit in with the humorous tone of the film. They also do a strong job making things interesting and keeping them moving, despite happening in what is traditionally a handful of bland places.

Weaknesses: Though it's enjoyable, it does still have some of the issues I've found with other Coen Brothers flicks. The characters are meant to be bumbling idiots, and it's funny, but it also hurts a handful of scenes as they become so ridiculous, they're hard to believe. Some scenes feel kind of useless and hard to get interested in, like the one involving Marge and Mike. There wasn't a ton in the ways of arcs or characters learning much, and by the end, I didn't get a true sense of accomplishment or closure.

Overall: I wouldn't consider it one of the best films ever or even of the 90s, but it's still damn good. It blends violence with suspense and dark comedy in a way that few other films can properly boast. It's a fun movie and sometimes, that's all you're looking for.

Murder in the Midwest!

The Coen Brothers are genius directors. They took the premise of a greedy Minnesota husband and brought it to vibrant life. Fargo is a dark, sarcastic comedy with such brilliantly funny satire of Minnesota and the Midwest lifestyle.

The characters are cheery, drole, and yet so quirky, you cannot help but be charmed by their banality. The mundane aspects of life are satirized by the Coen Bros. as ridiculous in the most extremely absurd ways. It's glory fun and a neat little depiction of small town American crime.

It's actually beautifully filmed and very well acted. The shots of snow, driving, or someone just walking across these Midwestern tundras are gorgeous. Frances McDormand, Steve Buscemi, Peter Stormare, and William H. Macy are all fantastic.

McDormand captures the genuine tenderness of a Midwestern woman while also giving her character the depth of a competent policewoman investigating homicides. Steve Buscemi is hilarious as the hitman just trying to get by and Stormare is wondrous as the sociopath sidekick. Macy plays the suburban Midwestern husband that's in over his head with such subtle finesse, he surprises you in every scene.

Everyone's accent will delight until you are so very annoyed at how quirky and sweet it all is underneath the horribly violent murder. Fargo is the Midwestern murder movie.

When I watch a film I haven't seen before, I seldom form a solid impression of how much I enjoy the film until at least the movie's midpoint, and occasionally not until allowing for a day to sort through my thoughts and emotions. Fargo is a rare exception, a film which grabbed my attention within moments of the opening titles. Carter Burwell deserves a large measure of credit, as his beautiful opening theme gave me chills upon hearing it for the first time and continues to do so every time I watch the scene ‚Äì I fully believe he deserved an Oscar nomination for his contribution. The theme is set to a shot of a car driving down a small road sandwiched between two snow-covered North Dakotan farm fields. The scene is so skillfully shot that it makes the mundane sight of a car driving along a snowy road visually interesting, an early hint at the skillfulness of Roger Deakins' cinematography. A few shots later, three of the main players are introduced - two half-witted criminals, the overly talkative Carl Showalter and the reticent Gaear Grimsrud, and Jerry Lundegaard, a hapless car salesman with an ill-conceived plan to solve his financial troubles, one so badly thought out that even the dumb-as-dirt criminals comment on the senselessness of it ‚Äì he is going to have the criminals kidnap his own wife.

The scene illustrates Fargo's brand of humor. It is rarely laugh-out-loud funny, but the combination of the exaggerated Minnesota accents, the quirky, bizarre, and sometimes abnormally polite dialogue, and the deadpan fashion in which the actors deliver this dialogue give the film a slightly surreal, humorous undercurrent which takes the edge off the occasional brutal violence. And there is a fair amount of violence, because in addition to a comedy, the film is also a blood-drenched crime thriller, albeit one in which the criminals are closer in competence and ambition to the burglars from Home Alone than Michael Corleone. The beauty of Fargo is that it works well as both. Some people watch it more for the humor. Others watch it for the dramatic elements. Whether you find the underlying story humorous or chilling, the storytelling is brilliant.

To illustrate the elegance of Fargo's storytelling, I present one of my favorite scenes in cinematic history - the famous TruCoat scene. Many movies, even good movies, present background information by having two characters tell each other things they should already know: "You're asking if your Jerry lies? Oh, you betcha, yah! He's terrible at it, though. I feel kind of bad for him when I see how his father-in-law treats him like dirt.". This scene is a master class on how to deliver exposition in a more interesting manner. After the establishing shot of the dealership where Jerry works, we see a hint at Jerry's own insignificance ‚Äì Jerry's picture hanging on the dealership wall, lost among a sea of other salesmen. This sense of insignificance is implicitly one of the reasons he tries his hand at crime. This shot is followed by an incredible exchange in which the Jerry attempts to deceive a couple into believing that an expensive sealant isn't optional. His lies are so blatantly transparent that the couple sees right through them, and Jerry even looks ashamed at his own dishonesty. All this exposition is accomplished without a single word of expository dialogue and while creating a scene which is fascinating to watch.

Jerry is a fascinating antagonist. He has such understandable motivations and is so inept and nonthreatening that he barely classifies as a villain, yet my sympathy for him was strained by the thoughtless evil of setting a risky, badly thought-out plan into motion and then sitting back with a look of bemusement as the bodies pile up. William H. Macy was dead set on playing the hapless salesman, and I find it hard to imagine the character without his stuttering mannerisms and snap on smile. The performance earned Macy a well-deserved Oscar nomination, and his character is one of my personal favorite villains, both on account of Macy's performance and the uniqueness of his character.

As important as Jerry Lundegaard is to the film's plot and as much as his character adds to the film, he is not the protagonist. The real protagonist, only introduced a third of the way through the runtime, is Marge Gunderson, a pregnant small-town police chief who becomes involved in the case after Lundegaard's out-of-control scheme results in the spilling of blood within her jurisdiction. Despite her late appearance, Marge Gunderson is not only the only character with a full character arc, but also the heart of the film. Without her, the film might come off as mean spirited, creating a bunch of evil, pathetic characters for the audience to mock. She is portrayed, however, as a smart, moral individual whose only flaw is being a tad naive, thus preventing the film from feeling like an exercise in schadenfreude. Frances McDormand plays the character beautifully, winning her first Academy Award for her portrayal of the character as a folksy but deceptively intelligent and strong woman, elevating an already strong and well-written character into my pantheon of movie heroes.

The supporting cast is also very strong, with a well-cast Steve Buscemi as Carl Showalter and an imposing performance from Peter Stormare as the silent Gaear Grimsrud. I struggle to find any faults in the film. Perhaps the statement at the beginning of the film that the movie is based on a true story (it's not) is a bit deceptive, but it is also a well-established literary device. Fargo also holds a special place in my heart as one of the films which got me interested in the medium. Without this film, I likely wouldn't be sitting here and writing this review. I originally watched this film several years ago, and 200 movies later I have yet to find a film I enjoy more. Perhaps this nostalgia makes me a biased reviewer, but even many critics without my personal connection to the film consider it one of the best movies of the 1990s. If I only ever convince you to watch one film, I would like this to be it.

Fargo is primarily a plot about a planned kidnap . . . but it's never really about a planned kidnap. No, the movie progresses as the various different characters find their own dilemmas, make mistakes and hastily try to clean them up.

I knew this movie was going to be good, let's be honest. Noah Hawley picked up this as a TV series for FX, so of course this was going to be good. I didn't know it was going to be this brilliant, though! The Coen brothers are apparently masters of their craft, with their beautiful shots and a confident way of storytelling. A story that jumps between several different perspectives of different characters could have become a confusing mess, but they managed to make it plausible and fun.

What makes Fargo so special? Believe it or not, I'd say their sense of humor. They're often very subtle, but I especially like how the script kept repeating the word "yeah" so that the more characters said it, the more comical it got, even when the situation was very serious. I just love how realistic it felt, from the reminder that "this is based on a true story" at the beginning to how we see the characters perform their daily lives. I don't know why, but it contributed to the humor within a dead serious narrative. I also loved the characters, too. They were all flawed in their own way(Jerry Lundegaard is the worst character, I think . . . at least Carl took a bullet to his cheek to pursue his goal, Jerry's a snake).

I've got a lot more to say if I wrack my head around a bit more, I'm sure. But that's the thing about my reviews, they're just my immediate thoughts about the movie, or at least immediate when I'm typing these words. If you're looking for an in-depth review, read another person's. This is just my feeling about a movie, okay? And Fargo is a great movie.

The ordinariness of the characters in this film are so carefully crafted, and if the scenes are carefully analysed in the light of all the information, the characters are really not simple and black/white as they seem. The Coen Brothers, being brought up in Minnesota, critique the Minnesota Nice nature - people with their plain and warm exterior with folksy speaking style, but not so empathetic or well-wishing from within; the characters are as cold and distant as the letters of the film title because the characters are as emotionally isolated as story's vast empty landscape. The accent and snow, the white and distant environment, all these things accentuate the feel of the living conditions and community of northern US. I can't testify to the accuracy of the time and place, but the Coens surely give us an intriguing character study.

The film takes quite a few witty jabs at capitalism and consumerism; it explores people's (here, especially Americans') obsession with fast food, television and cars. The realistic dialogues and quirkiness do make the characters stand out, like all Coen Brothers films. Many might say Marge Gunderson is the only character with good morals, but she isn't as pure as she seems. Marge, though an interesting character who defies prescribed gender roles and becomes our lead protagonist (though she enters only after one-third the film), she is as emotionally distant as the rest, as evidenced from her murder-scene inspection and ending ride with one of the kidnappers. Her routine life and by-the-book procedure, combined with her husband's not-so-sophisticated paintings about ducks and the decor of their house, exemplify the fact how they are a regular couple in a consumerist web so blissfully content in their simplicity and mediocrity.

Expectation vs what's given to us. From the opening title where it says that this is based on a true story and events are shown as it occurred, a certain expectation is set. The Coens take advantage of this liberty and tell the story in the most unusual but interesting way. But they subvert these expectations by slowly inserting scenes that people couldn't have known (if the events are being shown as they occurred). But this helps us understand the characters much better. (We now know that almost the entire thing is fictional, other than, maybe, the murder that inspired them.) The Coens do this throughout the film. Two other good examples come from the scene where Marge meets her Asian friend from college. Compared to the ways Asians are traditionally portrayed in films, Mike really stood out - not at all a clich√©d, accented Asian guy, but an emotionally unstable lonely guy who still stays with his parents in his 30s. And the story he tells Marge about his life, we immediately lap it all up, just like Marge does, not realising that the story had the exact plot details from 'Love Story'. The Coens surely take other such jabs at American pop culture. It's not what you expect from a true-story-based crime thriller. It's not what you expect from a comedy. Coen Brother films never usually fit into a single genre, and the unusual blend of crime and humour makes the film stand out.

And without Roger Deakins, the film wouldn't look the way it does. That parking lot scene has been praised and analysed to death by now. And yes, it's a spectacular shot and has so much to say. The acting from everyone in the cast is terrific, especially Steve Buscemi, Frances McDormand and William H. Macy. Macy gives us such a unique and memorably loathsome character - an apathetic, selfish and cowardly hypocrite, always maintaining such a cheery facade. But he represents the frustrations felt by the pawns in the capitalist system, rarely able to earn or save much to be financially or emotionally satisfied. Hence, his various schemes to collect enough money, run away and start a new comfortable life.

Though just a little less than 100 minutes, the film has been assembled with such attention to detail and innovation that it can be analysed and understood in so many different ways. It's not something that seems so great in the first view itself, but the more you see it or think about it, the more it lingers in your mind. Clever to end the film with the words "Two more months", since we know it might be a reference to the end of winter when the snow might melt and reveal the suitcase to a passerby.

A serious candidate for the Coens's best film.  The real stroke of genius here is adding Marge as the audience surrogate and moral center of the film.  There's a lot of films that deal with the stupidity of criminals (although not as spectacularly as here ... Jerry never seems to have anything approaching a coherent plan), but very few have a character as fundamentally decent and likable as Marge at their center.  It allows them to pull of the wonderful trick of having a deeply depressing conclusion of their narrative that seems somewhat uplifting by giving Marge the final say.

From the persistent buzz over the Coen brothers and the reputation of this film, many would and have argued that Fargo is an American classic. After watching it myself, I would beg to differ. For me, Fargo highlights an interesting conundrum I have stumbled upon in the last few weeks, which centers around my inability to zero in on anything that the Coen brothers have actually contributed to film over their illustrious 30+ years of directing and writing. Certainly, they have influenced pop culture in that films like Fargo, O Brother, Where Art Thou? and The Big Lebowski have become well known icons of American culture, albeit curiously disassociated from their creators. But in terms of film, I can't manage to hit on anything the brothers have offered. Kubrick pioneered abstract film and the portrayal of science fiction elements. Ridley redefined tension and introduced neo-noir. Lucas invented the modern blockbuster. Spielberg revolutionized special effects. All of these great directors left clear and obvious marks on every film they created and every film created since. The Coen Brothers haven't managed to do this. Instead they have carefully cultivated a mysterious, awards heavy fame that often gets them into GOAT conversations, despite the apparent lack of pedigree needed to even be in the same room. Fargo is a great example of this. Propelled by its quirky nature and a bit of artistic flair, the movie has become a powerhouse of great American film. In reality, Fargo is a well constructed dark comedy with a bit of slightly above average commentary on capitalism and the American lifestyle. Is the movie well crafted and filmed? Sure, but did it really change the game? I think the answer has to be no. If anything, the performances are what set Fargo apart, not the directorial style. Convincing accents and excellent poise from all of the actors involved are what define the movie. But overall, the film is relatively flat, a common problem for the Coen Brothers. Overuse of midwestern cliches, snow shots and a repetitive plot leave the viewer interested but unimpressed. The presentation is pretty common for the 90s, as is the tone. The American Dream commentary is interesting but ultimately infinitely better handled by American Beauty, released only 3 years later. The film also feels strongly dated, firmly anchored in the time period by an overfocus on certain cultural aspects. Compared to American Beauty, a film with some similar themes, Fargo just doesn't hold up. Mendes creates something timeless with American Beauty. The Coen Brothers were already behind the times when Fargo came out and the years haven't been kind. Ultimately Fargo is a solid film but it can't be considered a classic and it certainly isn't more than a single watcher.
Darkly Hilarious, Thrilling and Brilliantly Plotted, Fargo's both Storytelling and Setting elements are awe-worthy of a classic masterpiece crafted by the Coen Brothers.

As we read the text informing us that Fargo is a true story (which is a lie), we are introduced to the somber music which contains a medieval feel to it, being performed on harp to start, then switching to the use of more strings and drums.  This small portion of music is powerful in that it conveys exactly the tone of the movie: we know collectively as an audience that this will be an upsetting story which takes place in a fairly "innocent" location - Minnesota.

Why is this film titled "Fargo," exactly?  It is where everything is set into motion.  The William H. Macy character (Lundegaard) drives up there to meet the two "villains" of the story who he employs to kidnap his wife so that they may con money from his wife's father.  We don't know this right away, however; in fact, the information we're told is only certain bits, so we cannot fathom how simple this rather complex plan really is at first.  Making the situation complex for the viewer, however, lets us know that anything can and will go wrong - and what do you know, it does.

While Frances McDormand may be the protagonist of the story, let's talk first about the best talent in this film - William H Macy.  After watching this film, without knowledge of the show "Shameless," I doubt anybody could predict this actor would be a good fit for Frank Gallagher in Shameless - stubborn as hell, alcoholic, selfish, terrible father, anything but respectable.  In Fargo, Macy portrays Lundegaard with perfect execution, a role on the opposite pole of his iconic Frank Gallagher.  Lundegaard is a first time criminal, and it shows through the fact that he is an every-day-nice-guy, not very outspoken, and holds in his anger so much that he explodes when he needs to let it out.  Macy tackles the overall nervousness of the character so well that he develops perfect mannerisms for the character - looking down due to shyness frequently, moments of losing control that are just right and not overly dramatic, stuttering, and a stupid smile to retain his innocence despite the horrific plot he carries out, putting his family in danger time and time again.  Macy's portrayal is arguably the best performance of the film, yet he lost the best supporting Oscar to none other than Cuba Gooding Jr's role in "Jerry Maguire" that year.

Another strong aspect of the film is the character played by Steve Buscemi.  Everybody thinks it, and the Coen brothers say it time and time again in their script:  Steve Buscemi sure is a "funny-looking fellow."  This is brought up at least twice by witnesses in the case - one prostitute and one bartender, who act as substitutes for the audience, the voyeur, the cinephile who observes and comments, but does not contribute much to the actual story.  Buscemi's character is egotistical, funny, filled with rage; he is given authority which he does not deserve as Shep, who put Lundegaard in contact with Buscemi's friend, did not vouch for the Buscemi character.  Buscemi is the comic relief to his counter part's scary, more dominating and menacing presence - he is a giant compared to Buscemi and does not talk unless it has to do with the job they have set out to do.  This seems to be one of the only reasons Buscemi has to do practically everything - he goes alone on the actual "exchange" of the money and Mrs. Lundegaard, leaving only him to have to deal with the near-fatal surprise in store for him.  He returns with the money for his partner (though he does not tell him there is much more buried in the middle of nowhere) and he rightfully complains that Gaear did not suffer an injury like him, though his deception is greedy and egotistical.  It turns out that Gaear has a greedy nature too, possibly much greedier than Carl (Buscemi) since he thinks a sum of only eighty thousand dollars is involved and his reaction is very extreme.

Then we have Frances McDormand, playing Marge Gunderson, the protagonist who does not show up until thirty minutes into the film.  If it were not for the presence of this character in the film, this movie would be an extremely depressing story.  Marge represents the average Minnesota citizen who finds happiness with the simplicity of family life.  She serves the police force as she serves her family - she is the sole breadwinner for her and her husband Norm, and she is pregnant, yet embarks on this mysterious, dangerous journey to find two murderers in order to put them behind bars.  Her short speech to Gaear towards the end of the film is exactly what the film needs - it is reassurance that we are not alone in this world when we don't understand the evil behind greed which drives people to do the most awful things and strive so far from morality.
One final comment is that I love the presence of the character Mike Yanagita in this film.  Most people would find this character to simply be a comic relief character, but as my brother pointed out, the fact that he lied about his life and was so convincing about it drives Marge to return to Lundegaard, who appeared to be just as innocent as Mike on the surface.  To be honest, I thought this character was simple comic relief on first impression, but this didn't make too much sense to me since it did not drive the story further if that was the case, and I knew the Coen brothers are considered great filmmakers.

I very strongly recommend this film to all viewers who are comfortable with watching an R-rated film:  it is simply one of the greatest dark comedies/crime dramas ever made.

I feel like I'm going to be tried for blasphemy or something when I post this review. I know Fargo is a well-loved and respected film, but I'm starting to think I prefer the Coens' pure comedies instead of their attempts at blending drama with comedy. There's also a chance I was expecting something remarkable, so this was bound to disappoint. The story is actually surprisingly simple, in fact it's extremely reminiscent on Blood Simple. A husband hires men to hold his wife hostage in order to get a cut of the ransom money. Of course, as one would expect from a Coen film, crimes never go that smoothly. In fact Fargo is just a series of mistakes and clues for the cops to follow. Luckily, the cop becomes the protagonist of the film about halfway through. The fun of Fargo is entirely in the contrast of the serious events that are occurring, and the small-town friendly nature of people who live in Minnesota. William H. Macy is particularly fantastic as he perfectly embodies that classic Midwestern trait of bottling up negative emotions and putting on a friendly face even when your world is crashing down around you. I also liked Frances McDormand's character of Marge because she defies every expectation you might have about her from her appearance. She is friendly and sweet, but also a great investigator.

I think the biggest issue I had with this film was connecting with the characters and I feel that stems from the lack of depth given to most of them. It seems almost every person in this film is simply one-note. Jerry is frustrated and repressed, Marge is deceptively astute, Carl is horny and agitated, Gaear is evil, Wade is grumpy, etc. There is no character who has an arc either, no one grows or really changes because of these events, things just kind of happen. The problem that results from my lack of investment in the characters is that I started to feel like there was a lot of stuff they could have cut. It sounds horrible to say about a film that so many people adore, but in the long run Fargo felt like something they could have cut down to be a single episode of a police procedural on TV. I guess I'm just a slave to more traditional Hollywood film-making, because I think I would have had greater enjoyment if they focused in the entire film on just one side of the story, instead of bouncing around between 3 or 4. Naturally all of this complaining makes it sound like I hated the movie, which is not true. In fact I found it enjoyable, and had a few chuckles here and there. Expectations obviously played into my reaction to Fargo, because if I only planned on seeing a fun little crime drama I would have been satisfied, but since several people in my life celebrate it as one of their favorite films of all time it just couldn't live up. Still I recognize the aspects that people enjoy and appreciate the quality of the film-making in Fargo.

Fargo is at it's best when it actually focuses on Buscemi and Stormare. Their kidnapping job, while not an amazing story, is still interesting and fun to watch. However, whenever McDormand comes on screen I immediately lost interest in the film. Her character was bland, pointless, and down right annoying sometimes. Why did the movie spent so much time on her? So many of her scenes were just pointless, especially the diner scene she was in. That has to be the most pointless scene in the movie. Take her scenes out, the movie would hardly be different, in fact , it would be more interesting. All the scenes devolving into her personal lif add 0% to the movie.in addition to that, I fail to see the comedy in this film. I like Black Comedy: American Psycho, Seven Psychopaths, The Wolf of Wallstreet, Nightcrawler, etc. But I just couldn't find the humor in the film. If anything, it feels like a somewhat silly film that takes itself too seriously. The film is just honestly bland and extremely overrated. I can't say I hate it, but I can't say I like it either.

It's brilliant how all the characters get mixed up in each others lives. It's like a modern day Shakespeare drama. It seems every scene is funny or tragic, and every character is funny and tragic. And what a colorful cast. Everyone is unique and could star in their own movie. As a Canadian, I love their accents and mannerisms. Frances McDormand actually reminds me of my mom. But despite her performance, Buscemi and Macy were my favorites. Macy with his nervous energy and fiery temperament, and Buscemi who's just crazy in this movie. And the infamous wood chipper scene! The Minnesota setting makes a nice change and there's good use of the wintry landscape. Much of the humour comes from the the oddball, laconic personalities that  appear on the screen with whole chunks of dialogue being delivered in a monosyllabic drawl that is as painful as it is funny. Review In A Nutshell:

There it is. The first Coen brothers film where I can confidently say, "That was a great film!" The funny thing about it is that Fargo is a playful film behind its veneer of murder and greed; and it regards to themes and characters, I have seen brothers tackle much deeper. For the bulk of the film, I saw Fargo like I saw Pulp Fiction, it is purely entertaining fiction, or in this case non-fiction. It delivers interesting and quirky characters that keeps my attention on edge, there is always something amusing to see or listen to in Fargo; right down to the little mannerisms of its Minnesota characters.

Fargo starts out small, detailing a plot that feels simple and straight-forward, but then it starts to snowball, becoming much larger than anticipated. As the situation becomes larger, so does the greed of its characters; they feel that an increase in their work needs to be justified with a correlating increase of payout. The film however does not leave them as basic blueprints or generic archetypes, each character displayed on screen have character; shaped by its dialogue and personalities. Jerry Lundegaard, the man who started off with the plan, is the film's most grounded character and he plays difficult role of an sympathetic antagonist, at least for the first two thirds of the film; we feel sorry for him and in a way we want him to succeed as early on the film, he was cheated by those that are much greedier than him. The "true" antagonists of the film Carl and Gaear are wonderfully written characters, with distinct personalities, that makes them more than just villains; whether it may be the constant rambling of Carl or the dark silence of Gaear, there is more to their character than the villainous actions they perform.

The film's central protagonist, Marge Gunderson, is a plain cop who is just out there doing her job. For much of the second act, we follow her in this investigation, and even with her "lack" of exaggerated character, it never at all become boring to watch and this is because the Coen brothers have used the accents, mannerisms, and values of a Minnesotan that are enough to make up for what is missing. I say that her character is not exaggerated because she clearly isn't, it feels authentic and honest; the brothers simply just placed it in a script that is darkly funny. The character of Marge Gunderson is much more than just a character to follow, she also acts as a shining figure of what humanity should be; contented. This is a woman who is enjoying the simple things in life, being simply grateful of what is right in front of her, not letting the nature of her profession corrupt her in any sort of way; she lives her life and practices her profession with a bubbly smile and pure dedication. The Coen brothers make this more apparent through constant contrasting of the different characters, making the antagonists of the film always in a state of stress and confusion and her simply being her.

The performances in this film were no doubt strong but to say that Frances McDormand deserved the Academy Award, for me, is a bit of a stretch. She was up against the juggernaut that is Emily Watson, for her performance in Breaking the Waves, which to me was one of the best acting that I have ever seen in film. It may seem that I am proclaiming that McDormand is not deserving of praise, because she certainly does, not many actresses could play a role that is simplistic in character but at the same time quirky and memorable. The rest of the cast were also memorable, but definitely not as funny or as interesting as McDormand's performance, the closest that would match up to what she brought would be William H. Macy, playing a role that is constantly in a state of panic, attempting to get what he wants but at the same time doing so without losing face; he must be seen by his peers and the audience as a good and innocent guy. Steve Buscemi and Peter Stormare as the film's antagonists were also great, delivering hilarious conversations back and forth between one another, allowing the would-be dull moments feel interesting.

Fargo is a film that does not try to be ambitious, it simply is there to tell a story that is entertaining and original; and sometimes that is all a film needs to be great.

Jerry Lundegaard is a simple man, holding a simple job. He knows nothing about the complications in the lives of others, nothing about money, or even fatherhood. So too is Marge Gunderson, a Brainerd, Minnesota police officer who leads the life you would expect of a police officer in Brainerd, Minnesota. It's no wonder Jerry is out of his element trying to commit a crime.It's no wonder Marge has a hard time keeping up.

Set in the northern regions of the American Midwest, the Coen brothers place Fargo in isolation, with harsh snowy landscapes, imperviously iced lakes, and characters who pronounce "gophers" as "goe-fahs." Jerry (William H. Macy) is a small-time car dealer who quickly turns to deceit to conceal his ineptitude with money and investments. His eventual plan, to extort the father-in-law he loosely works for, requires him to cross paths with two lowly criminals, Carl and Gaear (Steve Buscemi and Peter Stormare). Unfortunately for Jerry, these two cronies hardly have a working relationship, simply looking for a payday (and perhaps a new car) from the deal. Following this whole dysfunctional team is Marge (Frances McDormand), whose simplicity is not to be misleading; this police chief is sharp in her logic, and would otherwise be quick on her feet (being 7 months pregnant slows you down a few steps).

Jerry's sudden divergence to a series of criminal acts is believable, and all the more intriguing, because he doesn't fit. His bewilderment concerning the fiscal demands of his hired hands is the little-league problems Don Corleone would laugh at. Jerry bites off more than he can chew trying to set up a job like he did, and repeats his mistakes trying to further extort Carl and Gaear out of their share of the profits.

Marge's bewilderment is simply due to the foreign nature of this new case. She first approaches dead bodies which were "randomly executed," not shot with a defined purpose. Admitting that Brainerd-ians died because they were simply "at the wrong place at the wrong time" is new and disturbing to Marge. When she finally catches up to the party she's chasing, Marge vocalizes her confusion: not as a ruthless detective, but more as the mother she will soon be, scolding the decisions that she simply doesn't understand.

Jerry and Marge provide the edge and intrigue the Coen brothers are so adept to bringing to their films. Similar to the acclaimed No Country for Old Men (2007), the two writer-director-producers don't rely on the violence and chases to keep the audience interested and occupied. The mood of Fargo follows the mood of its central characters, expounded by marvelous editing and cinematography. Even in a slow, dreary setting, the Coen's cinematic study of human greed in various forms (Jerry, Carl, Gaear) keep the film driving to its eventual conclusion, one which is perhaps expected but nonetheless insightful.

Fargo is pleasing in its pace and surprising depth. The simplicity of the preface leads the way to a more complex and uncharted storyline, pitting characters against one another who have equally important stories and motivations, and yet perilously opposing worldviews.

Over the past three decades, the Coen brothers have established themselves as a staple of American cinema. Not only have they written and directed some of the most quintessential works of the past thirty years, but their filmography is almost as eclectic as that of Spielberg or Kubrik. Every film that the duo makes has a different setting and atmosphere than the one before, something that I find very commendable. In 1996, the two brothers made the now-classic Fargo, a very risky entry in their diverse collection of works.

Fargo is a neo-noir film set in the cold state of Minnesota. William H. Macy plays Jerry Lundegaard, a struggling car salesman whose family is in a desperate financial situation. He hires two criminals, played by Steve Buscemi and Peter Stormare, to kidnap his wife so that he can get his father-in-law to pay the two a large ransom. However, the situation becomes much trickier when the bodies of a police officer and two civillians show up by the side of the road near Brainerd, Minnesota. Police chief Marge Gunderson, played by Frances McDormand, starts taking the case under her wing, and the deeper she digs, the more Jerry Lundegaard realizes the severity of what he's gotten involved in.

There were several choices made by the Coen brothers in Fargo that were unique for a crime film. For one, the story takes place in a snow-covered, rural area of Minnesota, a far cry from the urban environment that these films are usually placed in. I also thought that it was a strange choice to reveal the origins and events of the crime in the beginning of the movie, as these details are usually saved for a big reveal during the film's conclusion. Also, for the first twenty minutes or so, we are led to believe that the film's main character is Lundegaard, but soon after the first appearance of Officer Gunderson, the film focuses much more on the police chief. All of these choices made Fargo a very unique viewing experience, and the Coen's impeccable script made these choices work together almost perfectly.

The Coen brothers have been known to hire top-notch actors for their projects, and Fargo is no exception. Frances McDormand's performance as Marge Gunderson earned her the Academy Award for Best Actress, an accolade that was well-earned. Although her Minnesota accent is quite exaggerated, this lends to the more humorous side of the film, as Fargo is, at times, a dark comedy. William H. Macy is also great as the sociopathic Jerry, who we get a strong distaste for from the first five minutes of the movie. Steve Buscemi is fantastic, as he is in many of his collaborations with the Coen brothers, and Peter Stormare does a great job as a darker foil to Buscemi's character. All of these performances were perfect for the tone of the film, which shouldn't be surprising, given the casting choices of the Coen's other movies.

The direction and editing of Fargo is great, as well. Many of the shots of the cars driving through the frozen Minnesota landscape felt very immersive. They give the viewer a sense of what it would be like to live in an area so cut off from city life, and the difficulties of solving a murder case in such an area. There were a handful of scenes involving Marge that I felt were unnecessary at first, but looking back on the entire story, I now realize that these parts were important for her slow discovery of the details of the crime. The humor in the film was cut in and out and appropriate times, a feat that many drama-comedies cannot master. The narrative was smooth, the progression of the characters seemed real, and the entire story was masterfully created.

Fargo might not be the best crime/neo-noir film that I've seen, but I still think that it's a masterpiece. It's creative narrative and smooth direction worked well for the unique choices made in the story, and the fantastic cast made the material very believable. I'm also quite sure that this is a film that I will enjoy even more when I view it for the second time, something that I find happens with most crime/noir films. Fargo is a great addition to the Coen's impressive collection of work, and I highly recommend it to any fans of the noir genre.

I can't seem to explain to people why I adore this movie. I enjoy the characters accents, the mix of the mundane and the absurd, the snow dusted landscapes that bring me back to Saskatchewan and Alberta, the dark humor, the wholesome values of Marge Gunderson and her sweet relationship with her husband, the psychopathic violence fueled duo, Jerry Lundegaard's desperation and stupidity, and even the melancholic music. As far as flaws go, the only thing I could see criticism for would be the slow pacing. I totally understand that some people would find this movie boring. If you enjoy the things I described earlier and you are in the mood for a film that you can get lost in, I strongly recommend this movie. I know that I enjoy it with every viewing and I wouldn't change a thing. (9.5/10)

The humor is brilliant and comes mostly from the likable character Marge Gunderson, and the story does well to emphasize how exponentially pathetic and petty the kidnappers (and the client) are.  One of the most powerful scenes is where the kidnapped woman's son is just an anxious wreck about his mother but the father (the orchestrator) obviously feels no shame at all, not even for putting his own child through this.

"Geez" Frances McDormand stars as Marge Gunderson, a pregnant police chief whose affable, folksy demeanor masks a whip-smart mind. They've been hired by Jerry Lundegaard (William H. Macy), a car salesman under the thumb of his wealthy, overbearing boss and father-in-law, Wade (Harve Presnell). Jerry's raised some money illegally through a petty scam he's run on General Motors and he's about to get caught. This movie has one of the best writing in any other films, the dark comedy works in this film by the writing and the actors in the movie. the directing by Joel Coen and Ethan Coen was so well done and so fantastic no words can put how good it was.

Dark comedy is hard to do correctly. The Coen brothers deliver a quite insane comedy while being mind throbbing at the same time. There are many questions in the film about greed, power, and innocence. Most of the questions come from the main viewpoint of a police woman who is trying to piece the mystery caused by a car salesman who weaved himself into trouble. The pacing is perfect and knows when to take a break and give a little comedic moment even though it's still bizarre to laugh at. Dark comedy needs to be dark and yet still have a strong delivery and that can done wrong if done with no taste. Fargo has a great sense of how to do it write with scumbag characters and some innocent looking people who end ups trying to act calmly about everything even though he caused the whole problem. In the end, there is a question of how far money and power can cause people to go too far and it is something that cannot be answered as our police woman just has to do her job and live her life.

If you love the gritty yet comedic styling of the Cohen Brothers, this is your movie. Comedy and tragedy meet in the perfect way as we meet a financially struggling car salesman turn to crime to solve his issues. This movie reflects the struggle of obtaining the "American Dream" and shows just how far people will go to achieve it. You will watch two men collect a huge body count while providing some of the funniest parts of the movie, and you'll watch a pregnant cop hunt them down. This is a comedic, yet dark, thriller that you must see!

A masterpiece. When a moronic low life car dealer hatches a kidnapping scheme to trick his wife's father our of 750,000, it isn't long before things spiral wildly out of control. Everyone here does a fantastic job, but the stand out is Frances McDormand as the kind hearted, honest, and happy police officer who investigates the murders that begin to pile up (Steve Buscemi is also memorable as a manic kidnapper who continues to get the shit beat out of him throughout the film, getting worse and worse injuries as the film goes on). By the end of the film she is shaken by what she sees and is deeply saddened. She quietly chastises Peter Stormare's character (one of the kidnappers hired by William H. Macy's car dealer), saying "There's more to life than a little money, you know....dontcha know that?".  Indeed. Fargo is the film that put The Coen Brothers on the map, and I'd dare say it's still their best film.

"homespun murder story" is a fitting description -- the snowy plains of the upper midwest region is presented in rich splendor, while the quaint furnishings in the characters' homes bring a warm quality to the film's tone. Add to that the charming midwest accent, then we'd be hard-pressed to imagine anything gruesome could ever take place here, but it does -- an ill-fated decision motivated by greed ignites a brutal sequence of events where lives are needlessly ended. The warm and fuzzy tone of the film didn't quite seem an appropriate match to its the grizzly plot content, but in the end, Frances McDormand's pregnant police chief character becomes the moral voice of the film that saves it for me. As a side note, this film shares many similarities with No Country for Old Men.

One of the Coen brothers' most memorable efforts is the chilled thriller 'Fargo.' The film follows a series of murders that result from a botched phony kidnapping and ransom, and follows along with Frances McDormand's profusely pregnant police chief Marge Gunderson as she tries to solve the mystery. Aside from the smart dialogue, near-perfect upper midwestern accents and evenly balanced dry mild humor with shocking violence, 'Fargo' boasts a great cast that give the performances of their lives, led by McDormand and William H. Macy, whose smarmy car salesman character Jerry Lundegaard manages to be a likable yet pitiful villain. Of course, Steve Buscemi is probably the best casting match, as his creepy appearance really fits his kidnapping, murderous character. The Coens are also able to make a barren, snowy wasteland into an interesting environment in a way that gives it as much importance as the actors within it. Also memorable is Carter Burwell's grand score, which fits the mood of the film particularly well. Really, the only thing that puts a drag on 'Fargo' is the fact that it is such a depressing story. But putting that aside, 'Fargo' is a cinematic masterpiece that should be held in high regard for its artistic characteristics.
With a strong storyline and a beautifully made montage, Fargo is one good example on how movies with seemingly basic plots can, when written well, become extremely amazing.

When I finished watching Fargo, I could not figure out how to describe the film to other people. The consensus seems to be a crime story, with a black comedic edge. I now see Fargo as a farce in the darkest setting possible for the genre, darker than A Fish Called Wanda or Arsenic and Old Lace. It isn't groundbreaking cinema, but the fact that this extremely dark comedy pleased the old farts who hand out Academy Awards is awesome. Of course, I very much liked the film too. The setting is Minnesota, between the Twin Cities and a little town called Brainerd. Executive car sales manager Jerry (William Macy) needs money. Why? Too personal for it ever to be revealed. Through some connections, Jerry hires two men (Steve Buscemi and Peter Stormare) to kidnap his wife, so that her very wealthy father (Harve Presnell) pays a ransom necessary for Jerry's cause. But oh dear, antics occur when the two kidnappers shoot an officer who pulls them over, followed amusingly by killing two witnesses who watch Buscemi holding up the officer's body in a fashion almost as silly as Weekend at Bernie's. Officer Marge (Frances McDormand) of Brainerd is on the case.

Not all of the jokes deal with death, so if you are sensitive to death-related jokes, I apologize for your loss. I would hate to lose the ability to laugh at death. Steve Buscemi's funny-looking character (in any state) has the funniest moments. For a kidnapper, he seems to have most trouble with minute changes or errors. That dead officer pulled Buscemi over because he had no tags on his car. Buscemi can't even drive through a toll gate without losing his shit. I won't spoil my favourite Buscemi moment, but it wholly justifies my claim that this is a farce first. Office Marge deserves attention for being my favourite character though. She talks so sweetly in her naive Minnesota-Canadian accent (lots of 'Oh yah's), yet in the professional setting, she is the toughest officer in the squad. She rips through nonsense in interrogation, and apologizes a second later if she appeared to be rude. Every second of McDormand brought great joy to my face and heart.

Fargo benefits from the writers, the Coen Brothers, also being the directors. Nothing is lost in translation, and so the film sits right on the edge between comedy and crime, making for engaging and especially unique cinema. Again, I did not feel challenged when laughing at the especially violent and bloody deaths or demises of characters. I can laugh or wince. It doesn't matter what happens. Fargo does not need to amuse you in order to stand out for its high quality writing. However, the viewer who laughs is probably the one who is having the greatest time and would warrant repeated screenings.
Though incredibly violent and dark, it's comic personality and gripping story makes for a unique and memorable piece of cinema.
